207901: Crystalline Sliver.author: Mode
207901: Crystalline Sliver.text_parsed:
A staple Sliver deck card.
Since this guy has shroud itself, your opponent will effectively only be able to get rid of your Slivers by using mass removal spells, e.g. board hosers like Wrath of God.

But of course it does not suit into any Sliver deck - shroud also causes a lot of nonbos (or "bombos", as MaGo calls them).
You sometimes want be able to target your Slivers as well, e.g. when playing with Crypt Sliver or Magma Sliver.
In that case you should consider exchanging your Crystallines for Opaline Slivers.

I'm still looking forward to a troll shroud Sliver which can solve that problem ;)

207901: Crystalline Sliver.author: MysticSoldier5
207901: Crystalline Sliver.text_parsed:
@mix: They'll still be destroyed. Wrath of God and other such spells don't target. You can generally tell a spell or ability targets since it'll actually say "target" in the card text. (Examples: Lightning Bolt, Doom Blade, Giant Growth.) Also, Auras and Equipment target in order to enchant or equip, respectively. However, like most other spells in the game, you can counter Wrath-style effects. And if you're using this sliver, you're likely already in blue, so packing a few counterspells could help (if you particularly fear effects like Wrath, Negate might be a good choice).

As for this Sliver, I've not really played with it yet...or slivers in general for that matter even though I really want to. But it seems like it'd be solid even without fellow slivers, being a 2/2 for with shroud that can mess with a sliver deck's plans. Though I bet it'd really shine in a sliver deck since, as others mentioned, you can just use one of the sacrifice outlet slivers to get rid of it if you don't want shroud anymore.
207901: Crystalline Sliver.text_posted:

(Examples: [autocard]Lightning Bolt[/autocard], [autocard]Doom Blade[/autocard], [autocard]Giant Growth[/autocard].) Also, Auras and Equipment target in order to enchant or equip, respectively. 207905: Gemhide Sliver.author: Magnor_Criol
207905: Gemhide Sliver.text_parsed:
smiten, you can't ban a card - much less a entire, popular tribe - just because you keep getting beaten by them.

Sliver decks are extra-weak to removal because of how they work. Just keep breaking them down before they have a chance to build up. Mass removal is also a must for those times when they outpace you (or get a Crystalline Sliver out there).

As long as you know you're facing a sliver deck it's easy enough to combat them. If you destroy aggressively and never let them establish a foothold (Which they do very very fast) then you can beat them.

207908: Homing Sliver.author: casualhorror
207908: Homing Sliver.text_parsed:
An expensive Fauna Shaman/Survival of the Fittest for only Slivers on a Gray Ogre. Still is a good card even though it offers the effect for twice the cost for a fraction of the options. The number and power of sliver hatebears such as Harmonic Sliver, the awkwardness of most ability granting slivers in multiples, and the strength of having many singular slivers makes even this limited flexibility better or at least more necessary than it might be. To make this card Modern worthy it would need an all sliver combo to tutor up.... which would essentially make Sliver Tribal into a probably worse Birthing Pod deck. This is mostly because, like Survival of the Fittest, Birthing Pod is just way more degenerate.
All in all it still manages to be an exciting common, and that it theoretically could serve as a stand in for some of the most degenerate cards printed makes this a very cute card for the kitchen table. It may not make Spike's heartstrings sing but it has a home, as shown by its surprisingly high rating for its relatively low power level.

207911: Muscle Sliver.author: Henrietta
207911: Muscle Sliver.text_parsed: Depending on the slivers, it CAN make a huge difference. I have a casual U/G Sliver control deck involving plenty of counter spells, with Screeching Sliver being the only win condition - I never attack, because of using Slivers to tap things with Telekinetic Sliver and make mana with Gemhide Sliver to fuel counterpsells, and also having Dormant Sliver as a draw engine for Forbid, which prevents me from attacking altogether. Is my deck unique? I doubt it, I'm sure somebody else somewhere had at least some of the same ideas for how to build a control Sliver deck. That applies to making just about any type of deck. But my Sliver deck does play very differently (or, "wildly differently") from your typical Sliver deck. The Slivers you choose to build your deck around do make a difference, if you're actually choosing to build around them rather than just swapping out a random generic aggro sliver for another.

@Omega137: If it's just Ward Sliver that's causing you problems, you can fix that with a Ghostflame Sliver. Crystalline Sliver will still mess it up, though.

@gantz036: Iona, Shield of Emeria stops opponents from casting spells of the chosen color, but it doesn't stop them from using abilities. 207915: Sliver Overlord.author: kiseki
207915: Sliver Overlord.text_parsed:
This a tough EDH general to fight.

You can tutor artifact/enchantment/creature removal, life gain, evasion, shroud, protection from a color, poisonous, etc. Then, to make matters even worse, your 7-power, unblockable, untargetable, untuckable general kills with commander damage in 3 hits.

However, the raw power is NOT the problem.
The problem is that he plays the same EVERY game. It's boring. And counter to the vision of EDH:

"The Banned List for Commander is designed not to balance competitive play, but to help shape in the minds of its fans the vision held by its founders and Rules Committee. That vision is to create variable, interactive, and epic multiplayer games where memories are made, to foster the social nature of the format, and to underscore that competition is not the formats primary goal. It sets out to define the parameters of Official Commander while recognizing that local groups may wish to modify things to suit their own needs." -Sheldon Menery

207919: Virulent Sliver.author: endersblade
207919: Virulent Sliver.text_parsed:
I have a question. I understand that each virulent sliver stacks with other virulent slivers. However, I recently played against someone that said that with a virulent in play, each sliver in play basically has poisonous X, where X is the number of slivers in play.

He says that since the rules text reads "whenever a sliver deals combat damage to a player, that player gets a poison counter" and each sliver gains this set of rules text thanks to virulent, that the poisonous ability stacks from all other slivers.

Example: Virulent alone hits for 1 poison counter. Virulent and another sliver hit for 4 poison counters. Virulent and 2 other slivers hit for 9 poison counters, etc.

I don't believe this is correct. Otherwise, this would be the most broken card in the history of poison counters.

207919: Virulent Sliver.author: Ferlord
207919: Virulent Sliver.text_parsed:
I know I'm going to get some hate for this, but I don't see why Virulent Sliver is so good.

From what I understand, it's not like infect: Infect's ability is that damage dealt to a player is converted into poison counters. The amount of damage they deal is equal to the amount of poison counters given.

Poisonous 1, Virulent Sliver's ability, doesn't do that. Whenever they deal damage to a player, that player gets dealt 1 poison counter, regardless of its power/toughness. Even a 10/11 Sliver Overlord, pumped by Plated Sliver and Sinew Sliver will only deal 1 poison counter. The damage that it deals, however, is still there.

I suppose I shouldn't be so hard on it... It does stack (2 Virulent Slivers = each sliver gets poisonous 2) and it is a 1 CMC sliver.

Personally, I'd rather play Sidewinder Sliver and/or Plated Sliver. Flanking stacks, and I'm happier to attack with a 1/2 than a 1/1 poisonous 1.

207919: Virulent Sliver.author: Aquillion
207919: Virulent Sliver.text_parsed:
Its poison is pretty terrible (most of the time you'd rather just use a muscle sliver and kill them with damage.) But it only costs one mana, which is important -- slivers have few one-mana drops, and they benefit a lot from getting something out on the first turn (because as situational as its ability is, it still benefits from all your later slivers, too.)

Remember, one huge problem with this is that your opponent can just shut down your poison plan by killing your virulent slivers -- and even if they're at 9 poison counters, doing so will immediately make all those counters meaningless.

207921: Amoeboid Changeling.author: Lateralis0ne
207921: Amoeboid Changeling.text_parsed:
@Smokey

The creature type "wall" has been errata'd, as mm said, so that it doesn't automatically give the wall creature Defender. If a creature has Defender now, be it a wall or otherwise, it must specifically be listed in its text box. Thus, this and all Changling creatures (as well as the old mistform creatures) can now become walls without being automatically given the "this creature cannot attack" clause (namely, Defender).

They did the same thing when they removed the "Legend" creature type. It is now considered the supertype "Legendary", and creatures that were considered the type Legend are subsequently Legendary instead. (Done for reasons pertaining to Legendary lands, enchantments, and artifacts, to reduce confusion for players.)

207921: Amoeboid Changeling.text_parsed:
Note that the combo with Sliver Overlord breaks if you also have Crystalline Sliver or Ward Sliver out, since your Overlord won't be able to target the creature you want to steal. You can fix Ward Sliver by adding a Ghostflame Sliver, though.

Oh, and @TheHandyman: "Artifact creature" is not a creature type, it's a pair of card types. An artifact creature is just a permanent that happens to be both an artifact and a creature. This will, however, make its target a golem, and a scarecrow, and a construct, and a thopter, and so on, even if it's not an artifact creature, because those are all creature types.

207921: Amoeboid Changeling.author: EvilKhelso
207921: Amoeboid Changeling.text_parsed:
@CallmeMerry That Precursor Golem combination does not work. Whenever a Golem is the target of a spell or an ability that targets a single golem, before anyone has a chance to react, Precursor Golem's ability triggers. You are then to free to change any creature types you like, and then of course, once those spell(s) and its copies are to resolve, it checks to see if it is legal.

Example:
Step 1) Cast Eyeblight's Ending on Precursor Golem or any Golem.
Triggered Effect: Copy Eyeblight's Ending for each Golem it could target.
- - This also means, if there was a creature that was a Golem and an Elf like Amoeboid Changeling, this creature would not cause a copy to be created.
Step 2) Use Amoeboid Changeling's ability to give target creature all creature types.
Step 3) A copy resolves if any...a copy resolves...a copy resolves. You decide the order the copies go on the stack, when they are put on the stack.
Step 4) The original Eyeblight's Ending resolves. And if you use your Changeling on Precursor Golem, upon resolution, the spell would then be an illegal target.
~~ FIzzle Pop ~~ Your spell is countered.

Naturally, whenever anything resolves, each player has a chance to react.

You are then to free to change any creature types you like, and then of course, once those spell(s) and its copies are to resolve, it checks to see if it is legal.

Example:
Step 1) Cast [autocard]Eyeblight's Ending[/autocard] on Precursor Golem or any Golem.
Triggered Effect: Copy Eyeblight's Ending for each Golem it could target.
 - - This also means, if there was a creature that was a Golem and an Elf like [autocard]Amoeboid Changeling[/autocard], this creature would not cause a copy to be created.
Step 2) Use Amoeboid Changeling's ability to give target creature [a Golem in this case] all creature types.
Step 3) A copy resolves if any...a copy resolves...a copy resolves. You decide the order the copies go on the stack, when they are put on the stack.
Step 4) The original Eyeblight's Ending resolves. And if you use your Changeling on Precursor Golem, upon resolution, the spell would then be an illegal target.
~~ FIzzle Pop ~~ Your spell is countered.

207921: Amoeboid Changeling.author: Neo_James
207921: Amoeboid Changeling.text_parsed:
A potentially fun combo to use Amoeboid with Ludevic's Test Subject and Moonmist:

1. Tap Amoeboid and target Test Subject
2. Cast Moonmist
3. Since Test Subject is now "Human" it will transform and turn into Ludevic's Abomination

So for you get a 13/13 with trample instead of :D

Granted, the green/blue combo is a bit of a difficult to pull off, though not as hard now with Return to Ravnica block now added as well as cards from Dissension; Eventide and Alara Reborn. Again, this is a bit of a Johhny combo but a fun idea.

As for the card itself, really great ability that can lead to some fun ideas as you see above. :)

@Karthwine
Or in case you get hit by day of judgement. Slivers tend to massively overextend because the power of your army grows quadratically (going from 3 to 4 slivers is more significant than going from 1 to 2). This card will reload your hand after you've overextended into a board wipe.

@EvilCleavage
Also great for any tribal deck that can splash black. Don't get consumed by the fact that this card is black. It is only black because the effect it has is a black one (return creatures from graveyard to your hand). Keep in mind there is only 1 black mana symbol in the cost so as long as you have 1 black mana by the time you cast this (quite possibly later than turn 4), you're fine.

As for the card, I love it. So much card advantage for tribal pauper.

@TheRebel:
"Each creature gets +1/+1 for each other creature on the battlefield that shares at least one creature type with it."
So the changelings would only get +1/+1 from each other, since they have at least one creature type in common.

The cruelest deck you could run this card in would be a Changeling deck, followed by Slivers.

Simple solution: if you're playing another tribal deck, sideboard Coat of Arms. If you didn't know beforehand you'll most likely be able to tell by the time you have enough mana to play it, so don't play it.

No, it counts creatures, not creature types. The elves/goblins that were counted as shaman will not be counted again as elves/goblins.

I use this in my elf deck with Hunting Triad, Elvish Promenade and Rhys the Redeemed. I can easily get 15+ tokens, then play Overwhelming Stampede for lolz.

207927: Coat of Arms.author: sonorhC
207927: Coat of Arms.text_parsed:
In addition to the problem of boosting your opponents' creatures too (and if you're not careful you can easily end up giving away more benefit than you're getting), this also has another big disadvantage: It's really annoying to have to count up the bonus separately for each creature. Even if you're both playing tribal, it gets complicated due to most creatures having multiple types: Sure, all of your Soldiers share a creature type, but these two are also Humans, and share a creature type with three of your enemy's Allies, and oh, this one's a Goblin, that matches that dude over there, and wait, I've got a Changeling out, that gets all the bonuses, and...

And then you have to recalculate everything every time a new creature comes in, or one dies. Too much of a headache. Just use Door of Destinies instead; it's a lot simpler to keep track of (in addition to only helping you).

207927: Coat of Arms.author: Ferlord
207927: Coat of Arms.text_parsed:
I think it's hard to compare Sliver Legion to Coat of Arms. They are quite similar, but too different to say they're the same. To aid us, I made a Pros/Cons list:

PRO
- Sliver Legion is a Sliver itself, which can benefit from Sliver bonuses.
- It benefits from it's own ability and improves it, making it at least +1/+1 more effective than CoA.
- It can be played as an EDH general.
- It can be Tutor'ed with Sliver Overlord and/or Homing Sliver.
- Sliver Legion helps only Slivers. CoA can assist your opponent, if they are playing a tribal deck themselves.

CON
- Coat of Arms is colourless, which makes it much easier to cast. Sliver Legion is very difficult to cast ( can be harder to get than , depending on the situation).
- Artifacts are harder to get rid of than Creatures, making CoA more resilient.
- CoA can be later played in any other Tribal EDH deck, especially since it has no colour identity. Sliver Legion is restricted to 5-coloured Slivers.

From this analysis, I guess Sliver Legion is better than Coat... but only for Slivers.

On another note, goes GREAT with Relentless Rats and Shadowborn Apostles!
207927: Coat of Arms.text_posted:
I think it's hard to compare [autocard]Sliver Legion[/autocard] to Coat of Arms. They are quite similar, but too different to say they're the same. To aid us, I made a Pros/Cons list:

PRO
- Sliver Legion is a Sliver itself, which can benefit from Sliver bonuses.
- It benefits from it's own ability and improves it, making it at least +1/+1 more effective than CoA.
- It can be played as an EDH general.
- It can be Tutor'ed with [autocard]Sliver Overlord[/autocard] and/or [autocard]Homing Sliver[/autocard].
- Sliver Legion helps only Slivers. CoA can assist your opponent, if they are playing a tribal deck themselves.

CON
- Coat of Arms is colourless, which makes it much easier to cast. Sliver Legion is very difficult to cast ([WUBRG] can be harder to get than [7GG], depending on the situation).
- Artifacts are harder to get rid of than Creatures, making CoA more resilient. 
- CoA can be later played in any other Tribal EDH deck, especially since it has no colour identity. Sliver Legion is restricted to 5-coloured Slivers.

From this analysis, I guess Sliver Legion is better than Coat... but only for Slivers. 

On another note, goes GREAT with [autocard]Relentless Rats[/autocard] and [autocard]Shadowborn Apostles[/autocard]!

207927: Coat of Arms.author: ReneesAnatomy
207927: Coat of Arms.text_parsed:
To those saying this card doesn't work if your opponent uses something like Peacemaker or a board wipe: well, duh. It'd be pretty unfair and not at all fun if there was no way to get around this card. It's also why I keep instants and quick draws in my library and sideboard. ;)

This is probably best known as part of any strong elf deck, and that's usually how I use it. Yes, if your opponent has a tribal deck, it came come back to bite you in the arse. But the thing about an elf deck is that it's stupidly easy to spam the field with elf creatures. Use Elvish Piper to drop expensive creatures for 1 Forest, two or three Imperious Perfect and Elvish Promenade cards to add elf tokens to the field, and maybe Elvish Archdruid to give them all +1/+1 and make them a bottomless mana source. Your opponent may have 9 or 10 spirit/goblin/faerie/whatever cards, but if they haven't been spamming? You still get the upper hand. AND it makes it easy to use stuff like Wellwisher for 10+ life if your opponent has unblockable creatures.

It might be a bit less broken if it wasn't so easy for any old deck to play. 5 colorless mana for what could be an insane power boost? Ridiculous.

207928: Terramorphic Expanse.author: ICEFANG13
207928: Terramorphic Expanse.text_parsed:
@ Silas77 Yes his ability would be canceled because it checks twice: once when triggered (when Acidic Slime enters the battlefield it checks to make sure there is a legal target) and once when it resolves (the effect is happening, is there still a legal target?) It would happen like this:

Player A: Tap five forests play Acidic Slime (then there's a time where he's being cast if he isn't countered before he enters play his 'triggered' ability triggers) Acidic Slime has entered the battlefield I choose Player B's Terramorphic Expanse to destroy with his ability. (He must choose a legal target which unless it has shroud it most likely is).

Player B: Sacrifices Terramorphic Expanse to search for a Plains and put it on the battlefield tapped.

Player A's Acidic Slime 'triggered' ability checks again as it resolves, since Terramorphic Expanse no longer exists, it has no target and therefore is canceled completely. It doesn't get to choose a new target since the trigger of Acidic Slime coming into play has happened and it gets the effect only once.

And this card in almost any domain deck I would include 4 of. Also very good with landfall from Zendikar.

207929: Wild Pair.author: Zosk
207929: Wild Pair.text_parsed:
Unfortunately, if you have a Muscle Sliver and a Might Sliver in play, there is nothing in the premium sliver deck that you can search for. Each creature gets +3/+3, meaning Wild Pair will be checking either a 4/4, 5/5 or 6/6 power/toughness. This happened to me, but luckily, I was able to sac my Muscle Sliver to my Necrotic Sliver before Wild Pair resolved. This allowed me to search for a Fury Sliver (3/3) and end the game.

So in this particular deck, Wild Pair will not always be effective. However, there are a variety of ways to control (at instant speed) which slivers are on the board. I would prefer to have Sliver Queen or Sliver Legion instead, but Wild Pair is fun, and certainly can be useful.

207929: Wild Pair.author: Narsus
207929: Wild Pair.text_parsed:
To everyone gushing about how well this works with Slivers: it doesn't, or at least it works in a very limited way. It checks the power and toughness of the creature as it is on the field: in other words, your Muscle Sliver can't fetch itself, and if you use it to fetch a Watcher Sliver (2/2 while in your library), you'll have even more problems trying to fetch other Slivers.

That being said, it's very useful with a deck full of "bears". Ashcoat Bear and Whitemane Lion especially can work wonders with this card, just pumping out utility 2/2's. That would include guys like Avalanche Riders, Qasali Pridemage, Accorder Paladin, Wall of Blossoms, or Man-O'-War.

Cast Sage of Hours (P/T = 1/1, but gets 6 counters from the Biomancers), pair with Novablast Wurm (P/T = 7/7, but gets 6 counters from the Biomancers).

Take an extra turn. Destroy all other creatures and attack with your 13/13.

207933: Rupture Spire.author: agalloch
207933: Rupture Spire.text_parsed:
Slightly crappier version of Birds of Paradise. It comes into play tapped. Birds has summoning sickness. You have to pay 1 mana for this. Same for Birds. However, there are a few differences...

Better than Birds?
Can't be countered, unlike Birds.
You'll run into less land removal than creature removal.
Cost is colorless, unlike Birds.

Worse than Birds?
Can't play another land that turn, unlike Birds.
Can't be used to block in a sticky situation.

The first negative point is pretty big, so I'd rate this below Birds.

Birds = 5
Rupture Spire = 4.5
I dig it.

207935: Island.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
207935: Island.text_parsed:
Island has always been pronounced iland, it derives from Germanic roots, not the Latin insula. The spelling was modified because it was mistakenly believed to be related to the word isle.

twas brillig and the slithy toves did gyre and gimbal in the wabe all mimsy were the borogoves and the mome raths outgrabe Beware the Jabberwock, my son, the jaws that bite, the claws that catch, beware the Jubjub bird and shun the frumious Bandersnatch He took his vorpal blade in hand, long time the manxome foe he sought, then rested he by the Tumtum tree and stood a while in thought. While in an uffish mood he stood, the Jabberwodck, with eyes of flame, whiffled through the tulgey wood, and burbled as he came! One, two, one, two, and through and through the vorpal blade went snicker-snack he left it dead and with its head he went gallumphing back. And hast thou slain the Jabberwock? come to my arms, thou beamish boy! Calloo, callay, what a frabjous day! he chortled in his joy. Twas brillig and the slithy toves did gyre and gimbal in the wabe, all mimsy were the borogoves, and the mome raths outgrabe.
